Google causes this problem. There are three steps to fix it. 
1. Go to settings - application manager - all - google app. Uninstall updates. This sorts the problem, until of course google automatically updates itself, so...
2. Then open google play. Tap the three lines at the top left corner. Then settings and turn off automatic updates. That will stop the auto update happening. 
3. Finally; the repeated tapping of the home button you've been doing has probably messed with the accessibility settings. Go to settings - accessibility - dexterity and interaction - then turn on interaction control. (Why? Because triple clicking the home key turns it off, which many of us have been doing, trying to get back to the home screen).
These three steps worked for me. Back to normal.

title: USB cover easy fix

thread.text:
I've had my S5 Active for almost a year now-the other night at work, the USB port cover fell off-I looked online to ifixit and noticed that disassembling the phone is a pretty involved process, and a google search found that it's an ongoing source of criticism of Samsung. I took a closer look and saw that the cover comes in two pieces-the cover itself and the 'connector' flexible piece that connects it to the case-it looked like they were glued together and the glue wore out-a quick, very careful dab of superglue and I was done, no disassembly required.
Hope this helps somebody
Jim B

title: Help I locked myself out of my phone last night

thread.text: Put a. Passcode on my phone while I was drunk can't remember it HELp!

Greetings! Welcome to Android Central.
Just curious here, do you have a Google account? If so then:Go to AuthSubTokens and enter your login details to see if your Android device is listed.If your device is listed, it will be shown as an "Android Phone"Revoke access for the device.Generate a new password.At the bottom of the page, you will see an option to "Generate New Application-Specific Password".Enter any name and click on "Generate Password".A 16-digit password will be generated.Enter this new password in your Android device, along with the correct Google ID.If the "Generate password" option is disabled, you'll need to enable 2-Step Verification.Follow the 2-Step Verification link to Google, and set up 2-Step Verification.Depending on your device, you'll receive options from Google to generate a new password and access your Android device using the 2-Step Verification process.Hope all works out for you.

The reason the phone tells you it's full, is there is reserved storage for the OS. If you have any apps that you don't use, I would get rid of them to help free up space. title: Why isn't my S5 Active charging?

thread.text: I've had my S5 Active for just a couple months, now. Last night, I tried charging it and when I plugged it into the wall charger, it would show that it's charging for a couple seconds but then would say that the charger was unplugged, even though it wasn't. I'm using the original charger that was given to me and I'm pretty sure it's not damaged yet. I plugged it into all sorts of working outlets (and computers) around the house and experienced the same problem. An article online suggested lifting up the tab inside the USB port in the phone, so I did but it didn't help. Every time I try charging my phone, it only works for a few seconds. I have to shamefully admit, though, that just before, I took my S5 Active and washed it with shampoo... I'm pretty sure I rinsed and dried it thoroughly, but it might not have been enough. So, what do I need to do to get my phone charging again? Thank you!

Washed the outside? Or got some shampoo (even a few drops) inside?
If inside, what you can do now it get all the data off it, do a factory reset and find a garbage can. By now it's so corroded inside that it would cost more to clean and replace parts than it would to buy a new phone.
If you're sure it's never been wet inside, gently move the plug where it goes into the phone when charging stops and see if that gets it charging again. If so, you need a new charging port. (The part isn't expensive - the labor to replace it will probably bring the repair into the $50-$100 range.)
(Remember, the phone is water resistant, notwater proof. The pressure of water falling a foot from a faucet is enough to force water into the phone. It will resist being used in a rain heavy enough that you're running for shelter, but not 2 seconds of spray from a hose at 60 psi. Regardless of the videos you've seen, treat a water resistant phone as if it could melt like sugar, the same as any other phone. Then, when you put it down, and there's a little puddle of water on the table, the phone won't be damaged the way non-water-resistant phones will be.)
i am having the same issue! have you fixed yours yet? any suggestions? I have a small feeling that its not the plug but its the phone itself... please get back to me! - Reese

title: Is the Samsung Galaxy S5 Active waterproof?

thread.text: Is Samsung galaxy s5 Active waterproof in sea water (salt water) or it is just in fresh water?

Welcome to Android Central! It apparently carries not only an IP67 rating (which is for fresh water only), but also a MIL-STD-810G rating, which includes salt water. But it's worth pointing out that the water resistance is not a 100% foolproof guarantee. If there is any break in the integrity of the casing (from trauma, or from an open, loose, or faulty USB port cover), then water will get in and cause damage. And salt water will cause more damage than fresh.
Should be waterresistant not waterproof.

title: How can I protects the headphone slot when I put my Samsung Galaxy S5 Active in the water?

thread.text:
i know that the phone comes with IP67 Certified and a MIL-STD-810G rating, which includes salt water. BUT when i will put the phone in the sea water will the slot for headphones work fine when i get the phone out of the sea? Because it is not covered
thank you

Welcome to Android Central! It is apparently sealed on the inside, so the jack doesn't need a cover. http://forums.androidcentral.com/sam...aterproof.html. But this is assuming the integrity of the seal doesn't become compromised at some point.

And sea water in the jack will eventually destrou the jack, so give it a few soaks in fresh (not salt) water as soon as you get it out of the salt water (don't let the salts dry inside the jack). I'd use an eyedropper to make sure that water actually got into the jack, then immerse it in a shallow pan of water and swish it around a few times. Then change the water, shake the phone to gt any water out of the jack, do it all again. At least 3 times. Then a shot of rubbing alcohol into the jack to absorb any remaining water and a final shake.
(I treat an IP67 rating as "if it's not raining so hard that you'll drown, the phone will probably be okay", not as "you can go swimming with it".)

replies.text:
Welcome to the forums!
No the jack is not waterproof, though some have had no issues once it dried and some still did, and there are plugs you can buy for it. The S5 is not a phone to be used in the water, it is not a waterproof phone. It is a water resistant phone, only for accidents. It is not meant to be an underwater phone/camera.

title: Should there be a VPN on my S5 Acive, I just activated at store yesterday I DID NOT CREATE ANY VPY?

thread.text:
When I go to mobile networks is shows after the new phone was activated I click on logs this is what it says 18:08:24ackage version is vpnclient-3.0-src-package-vpnclient-3.0.2-969-r5430-2014-03_12-30-07.
18:08:24:vpnclient is now running with uid1000. 
Is this normal

The vpnclient is just a client that runs on your phone in case you want to access a VPN. If you had an active VPN connection, there would be an icon that looked like a key in your status bar.
The log message is benign... your phone is a portable Linux computer and there are a bunch of clients and daemons that run that you may not ever ultimately need or use.
yes you can

title: Bluetooth volume levels

thread.text:
Hi,
When my software did the big update I notice something going on with the Bluetooth volume when playing media files. The volume level line is half orange. I also noticed that it doesn't seem to play as loud as it used to. I used to be able to set my car volume at about a 10. Now I have to crank it up to the high 20's or 30's. The phone only occasionally mentions the dangers of listening at high levels and when I say ok it will increase a little. 
Does anyone know why this is? Does Android no longer trust me to make a decision? 
Thanks

replies.text:
There could have been a change in the way Bluetooth handles the audio output for safety purposes. It's not that Samsung or Android doesn't trust you...it's just that they need to error on the side of caution since something like this can potentially cause ear damage if volumes are too high, especially with a set of Bluetooth headphones.
You can try clearing cache in recovery: power off the device. Hold home+volume down+power button until the recovery screen loads. Use volume down to highlight "clear cache" and power button to accept. Reboot and see if that fixes it.

title: How can I set my Linksys router to work with my Samsung Galaxy S5 to set up custom maps for a game?

thread.text:
I play ARMA 3.
To set up hosting custom maps I had to do a few things. On my home-based Linksys router I did this :
1) I triggered ports 2302, 2303, 2304, 2305 for both TCP and UDP.
2) I set my desktop static IP as 192.168.1.113
3) I had to figure out the service provider DNS address (ie. the Internet Service Providers DNS address). My service provider for my home router is not AT&T.
So....
How would I do this using my Samsung Galaxy S5?
I know of a program Port Forwarder, but I don't want to forward ports, I want to open them. My service provider for my phone is AT&T.
Thank you.

title: Used s5 active

thread.text: Just bought my husband a s5 active, phone seems to be in great shape except battery is draining extremely fast. Could it be that I just need to buy a new battery. If so can anyone recommend a good one. Thank you in advanced

Do you know how old the phone is? The battery certainly could be failing. Any replacement battery should be fine, but to be safe, stick with reliable brands like Anker, Seidio, or Zerolemon. Of course, a genuine Samsung battery would be safest, but not absolutely necessary.
Thank you for your reply, not sure on how old the phone is. I will try one of those brands on amazon. Thank you very much

I would go under "Battery" in settings toward the end of the day, and see what it says first. You may have an app that you don't realize is using a ton of juice. After the last System update, first Facebook Messenger, and then Facebook itself both started to drain my battery like crazy. I uninstalled, and reinstalled both and the problem went away.
Basically, if anything other than "Android System", "Android OS", or "Screen" are the top users of battery, that app is probably running in the background and needs removed and reinstalled. If this isn't the case, then yes, you may need a new battery.

title: Does anyone have an S5 that works correctly?!?

thread.text:
I have had my Galaxy S5 Active now for about 3 months. In that time I have reset it to factory defaults 4 times and it screws up differently every time. Here are just a few of the issues I've had to deal with on this brick.
1) Speech to text doubles up on a text. Try saying "Hello, how are you" and you get "Hello, how are you.Hello how are you".

Welcome to Android Central! It's possible that some app you keep installing is causing instability. Try booting into Safe Mode, which temporarily disables all 3rd party apps. https://support.t-mobile.com/docs/DOC-10696
If the problem disappears in Safe Mode, then something you installed is causing the problem. You may have to uninstall apps one by one until the problem disappears. If the problem persists in Safe Mode, then it's more likely to be a hardware or firmware problem.

Well, I sure am sorry that you're experiencing so many issues, and I was in no way implying that you're a novice. Please understand that Android Central has members of widely varying experience, and I never assume that a member is an expert. 
You are correct that one of the problems with Android is the fact that it's so open--which means that multiple different manufacturers can design hardware for it and also modify it to varying degrees to make it more distinct from that of other manufacturers. Combine these varying modifications of Android with the challenge that app developers have of making apps that are compatible with the many kinds of hardware and firmware, and you'll inevitably find some incompatibilities that arise. That's why I suggested Safe Mode as a starting point--but the fact that all of the problems persist in Safe Mode suggests it might be a defective unit that you have, or perhaps corrupt firmware. Consider reflashing the stock firmware: http://forums.androidcentral.com/amb...interface.html
And I'm not sure if you were addressing this site directly or in more of a rhetorical way, but just to be clear, Android Central is not directly affiliated with Google, any device manufacturer, or carrier. Hope you are able to resolve your issues in one way or another.

Welcome to the forums. Rooting is like the cliche of 'With great power comes great responsibility'. Once rooted, you probably won't get any updates. They will most likely fail. But some of the advantages are offset by the fact of what custom recoveries and other root only apps can do for you. 
In the Gingerbread days, rooting was more commonplace, and needed if you wanted to do many things. Now....a lot of what used to need root access is embedded in the OS.
Rooting can possibly brick your device. The chances are minimal, but still possible. 
I am starting to have the opinion that rooting is losing some of it's appeal. But that is just me.

title: Battery suddenly draining extremely fast.

thread.text: I have an s5 Active that is about 6 months old. One of the things I love about it is the battery life. At least it was until about a day ago. I noticed the battery was low, like 19%. I didn't plug it in right away because I usually have at least an hour before it gets lower than 15%. Less than 20 minutes later, it was at 10% and it went down to 7% by the time I got the charger and plugged it in. This was odd, but I didn't think much of it. I left it plugged in until I went to bed and it was at 99%. Normally, I turn my phone off at night but left it on because I was expecting a call rather early. I left it in sleep mode, but found it was off when I got up (thankfully, I didn't miss the call). When my boyfriend turned on the phone, it was at 10%. This has never happened before - the battery dying after being left on but inactive for 8 hours. I looked online for reasons why this would suddenly be happening and tried some of the tips, including restricting background data, and power save mode. Not only is it draining when it's not being used, when I go online, it drains even faster -nearly 10% in less than 45 minutes. I'm not streaming anything, just basic browsing. I haven't installed any new apps nor updated any in the past week. I'm a little perplexed and would like to know if anyone else has had a problem like this and what I can do about it. Thank you.

Constantly draining the battery that low gives you about 300-400 charges before the battery is totally dead (and it starts losing capacity after only a dozen cycles like that). If you fully charge a new battery, then use it until the phone tells you to recharge it, and repeat that twice more, then never let it get below 40% if you can help it, you'll get a LOT more life out of the battery. If you need more time than 60% of the battery can give you, carry a charged spare.Two batteries and a charger that will charge both the phone and the battery out of the phone are only $23.

I don't normally let it drain all the way down on a regular basis. In fact, I usually keep it plugged in until it reaches a full charge, regardless of how low the battery may or may not be. Even still, my biggest concern is how rapid it started draining literally in the past 24 hours. For example, I put my phone down and let it sit, unused, for an hour. It went from 68% to 63% and since I've been online for the past 10 minutes it went from 63% to 60% (and down to 58% since I wrote this part). I've had several cell phones over the years and none of them have had battery drains like this and as suddenly as this. My boyfriend's phone, which is 2 years older, can be used all day long before it needs to be It wasn't like it just slowly stopped holding a charge as long as it used to. It just, yesterday, My boyfriend's mom and sister both have Samsungs, one is older and one is newer than ours. Neither one of them have a problem with their batteries draining as fast. My boyfriend's mom constantly lets hers die before she charges it and it's much older than ours. I shouldn't have to replace the battery within 6 months of purchase - no rechargable battery I've ever had has lost its ability to hold a charge so quickly.

Ok question, so if you just wanted to buy a new battery for the phone just overall, do you recommend going to samsung site or amazon. Mine was doing better but I had location off and would turn Bluetooth off when not using. Got a gear fit for Christmas so Bluetooth is always on now. 7 hours later from charging today my phone is now at 53%. I'm frustrated as this used to go at least 24 hours. Thinking because the myth we had always heard was let the battery drain a few times then you didn't have to. When we first got these phones in October we did just this as we had iphones before and did that. After reading many times on here that's not something you should do, I'm wondering if that didn't affect it as well.

I turned off background data and put it on battery saving mode and that really helped keep the battery from draining when we weren't using it. I do notice the battery drains a lot faster when I'm online, but nothing like that one power drain. I'm not ready to buy a new battery for the phone because the phone is less than a year old...although if and when I do decide or need to get a new battery, I'll probably look at Samsung and then see if I can find it on Amazon for a better price. I wouldn't go with a generic battery though.
Buy a new battery off Ebay. Way cheap.

Mine is starting to drain alot faster too I was told from the people at AT&T to call Samsung since my phone is still under warranty they would send me another one but I have yet to do so but plan on giving it a shot
Posted via the Android Central App

I mean don't get me wrong it works a little but I'm on power saving and it's at 83% and I literally took it off the charger 10 minutes ago at 100% and u wasn't doing anything that would drain the battery so fast. title: what's rooting about

thread.text:
I see it talked about everywhere but never done any added benifits for rooting my phone and just in general what is rooting ??
Posted via the Android Central App
Rooting - is it for me? Some Q&A
rooting is unlocking your phone's system so you can remove bloatware,customize roms and stuff like that.

First, you need to determine if you must root the phone to accomplish a particular thing you need or want to do. Or, if not then maybe you just want to experiment. Nothing wrong with that, but there's some things you should know and consider first to avoid unnecessary grief.
Rooting grants full administrator permissions to the user, rather than limited user permissions. The good is that this allows you to do basically anything to any files on the device. It allows full control of everything on the device. The bad is that it also means you have full permission to muck up anything on the device. It also reduces the security of the phone somewhat.
I used to root every phone I had. But I no longer root my daily driver phone that I cannot do without. As hardware and software has improved the need to root has declined. Now I do not recommend rooting unless you have a specific need or just want to experiment on a spare device.
If you decide you really do need and want to root, first do a LOT of reading. See if there's a subforum here for your phone. You should check out the XDA Developer forum for information too, but be sure to read first and post later there as it's not a very n00b-friendly site. And as always, for questions this forum and Google search are your friends.
There's some chance a mistake could 'brick' your phone (make it unusable). Make sure you understand why you're rooting, the exact procedures required and all the terminology. And it's absolutely critical to have a recovery plan and backups in case things go bad.
DO NOT try to install a ROM that is intended for any phone except your exact model! If you have questions post back here before proceeding and someone will help.
Don't forget to do backups! Read about nandroid backup.
Until you are confident that you have everything above ready and understood, you're not yet ready to root.
Android since v1.0. Linux user since 2001.

title: App for Battery Usage

thread.text:
Can anyone suggest a good application to show me what is using all the battery life on my S5 Active? I've had the phone since last July and up until about a week or 2 ago, the battery life has been pretty decent. However, lately I'll only get about 7 hours before it is below 15% from being fully charged....AND this is only texting a few times and one call. I have a suspicion there's an app that's causing this but, I'd really like to figure out which one is is and get rid of it! 
Thanks!
You can try Gsam. It's got a free version in the Play Store.

That's 7 months of discharging the battery to 15% - that alone could have caused the problem. Lithium batteries don't last long if discharged past about 40%. (The ideal charge spot for longest battery life is 50%.)
The Battery listing in Settings will show you what percentage of battery use is being taken by each app with an appreciable amount of usage. (You really don't care about an app that's using 0.01% of the drain.) Most likely, though, you're going to find about normal drain from the usual apps. The screen, Android System and Android OS will usually be the largest consumers. If the signal from the tower is a bit weak, Phone Standby may also show up near the top. (Remember, the percentages are percent of power being used, not percent of total battery power. If 5% of the battery capacity is being used and an app is using 10%, it's using 0.5% of the battery capacity - 5% of 10%.)

Thanks I took a screen shot of the battery settings showing usage (included here) . Yes screen and operating system. But noticed Google play services was up there. Is that normal?
Posted via Android Central App

So downloaded gsam and it shows about the same thing except media is using be most of the battery according to it. Guess it's time for a new battery. Sigh...
Posted via Android Central App
Media battery drains sometimes are related to a corrupt file in an SD card. If you have one take it out and see if that makes a difference.

title: Photo questions

thread.text:
Are there any apps that can do the slow motion like the iPhone? 
I've also researched and I cannot get these stupid pics that are in picasa mode to delete. I've read and read and it always comes up with it saying unsupported file if i select it to delete. How can I get these off my phone?

Photos that are on Picasa probably means that they're in your Google+ Photos album in the cloud. Picasa was acquired by Google a while ago, and essentially became Google+ Photos. Not all gallery apps allow you to delete cloud photos, so go to your Google+ Photos page in your computer browser, and see if you can find those photos. Delete them using the computer browser. That should get rid of the photos on your phone after it syncs. If it doesn't, then go to the App Manager, select Gallery, and Force Stop, then Clear Cache/Clear Data. When you open it again, wait a few seconds for the database to repopulate--those cloud photos should be gone.
Not sure about any good 3rd party slow motion video cameras. You could try HTC's Zoe app, which they recently made available for all phones.

title: camera

thread.text:
What's everyone using settings wise on the camera
Posted via the Android Central App

That depends on the scene. Fast shutter (which means smaller F-stop) for motion, slow shutter and large F-stop for really dark, but non-moving, scenes, etc. The same as with any other camera, a 1934 Voigtlander, a new Hasselblad or the camera on a phone. The laws of physics haven't changed much due to the advent of cameras in cellphones. (Neither have the laws of photography - a great photographer can get a better picture with the 2MP front camera than someone who knows nothing about photography using a 42MP rear camera.)
Your question is something like "At what speed does everyone drive?" I don't do 70mph in my driveway and I don't do 10mph on the interstate.
You use the settings most appropriate for the situation that your camera app (and camera) is capable of.
Maybe next time you could leave out your bitchy editorial commentary and simply provide some helpful feedback. The general 'laws' of politeness are also still the same in our cellphone age.

It's a great phone, has a lot of life, just a few quirks here and there.

title: So it finally did it, called 911 in pocket...

thread.text:
My boyfriend decided to take the Casemate Hula bumper off his phone, since the case couldn't hold up to being in a factory workers pocket 12 hours a day (it broke). So instead of getting a different case, he hasn't used one. Instead, he decided to lock the phone with the pattern lock again, that way it wouldn't pocket dial anyone so easily. Bad idea.
AT&T hasn't put out the 4.4.4 update that stops being able to pocket dial 911 so easily when the phone is locked.
Last night at 3:30am, I was just sitting here playing video games, when all of a sudden I see a flash of light. My boyfriend wasn't home from work yet, so I figured it was either him or one of his friends pulling into the driveway. I heard the door bell, so I went to go see who it was. It was two policemen. Great! I freaked out, because usually the cops aren't at our door.
The one cop wanted to know if I was okay and that a number called them that was associated with my name and address (the account is in my name). I told him that I didn't know the number, only because I couldn't think right then. They apologized for giving me a small heart attack and left.
I called him to make sure he was okay and told him about the cops. That's when he checked his phone and noticed he actually did dial 911 from his pocket. First time that has ever happened from any phone we've ever had. I wish we could get the update, so it's not so easy to do.
Sent from my Galaxy S5 Active using Tapatalk

title: Caller ID wrong on Galaxy S5 Active

thread.text:

I haven't downloaded any third party apps, I restarted my phone and it still happens, not only when she calls, when anyone calls with a contact ID picture, the next call(s) that don't have a picture all show the last contact ID picture. 
Not sure why - anyone????

Try resetting your system cache, this won't change any data personal or otherwise on your phone:
Hold Up Volume, Power Button and Home button at the same time for about 1 second, till the splash screen appears (top left will say, entering recovery).
Use the vol up/down to scroll down to Wipe Cache...once its highlighted, hit the power button to select it. Once its done, reboot and see if that corrects the problem.
Let us know.

title: Battery Life

thread.text: So, I've only had the S5 Active about 2 weeks after defecting from Apple lol. So far so good, learning new things daily. Now, I've let my phone completely die about 7 times before possibly keeping it plugged in while at work while listening to music and so forth. I've noticed that the phone can go for over 24 hours before being charged but now all of a sudden the battery goes down quickly now. I'll take it off the charger at 100% and immediately it will go down to 99. From there I can maybe look at a few things and it be at 95%. I close all apps out when finished. is this normal for it to jump so quickly on a drain?

Welcome to Android Central! There can be various factors at work. It may depend on what the device is doing in the background. Sometimes a reboot helps, and sometimes you may want to wipe the cache partition: Reset: Samsung Galaxy S 5 | T-Mobile Support

Comparing life over 24 hours to how quickly it goes down to 95% doesn't mean anything. Does it now last a lot less or does it still give you all day performance with a substantial amount of battery left when you recharge (comparable to the 24 hours you mentioned)? If not, have you recently installed new apps? It may be a rogue app that's draining your battery if indeed your battery is draining more than previously.
Posted via the Android Central App

Thanks! I can still get a full day (except for today due to lots of use). I just was confused on how I could take it off the charger at 100% and within minutes it already be down to 95%. I thought maybe a strong start and then something I did wrong to make the battery all wonky. I stumbled across by accident where it told me what apps were running in the background that used a high amount of ram. Not a clue how I got there. I will however review different things as far as the wiping cache and maybe an app recently downloaded. Regardless, extremely happy with this phone and the choice to move away from iPhone.

Oh one more question. I've let the phone die quite a few times as I've always heard it's best to do that with a lithium battery. Is it OK to keep it on a charger all day after you do that about 6 or 7 times or do you recommend letting go the phone completely die each time? With the iPhone I'd see it was at 35% and throw it on the charger or if I was at work all day streaming music....charger. suggestions?

It is not a good idea to let lithium batteries die on a regular basis. The more you do this, the more chance there is that you'll accidentally let the battery sit without charging after the automatic shutoff, which can lead to the battery draining to true zero. Then it's irreversibly dead.
Some authorities recommend charging when you get down to around 40%, to maximize total battery life. Letting it sit on charger shouldn't impact overall battery life--you can't overcharge, and the device itself is smart enough to reduce the current it's getting to a tiny trickle.
Ok that makes complete sense. Thanks to you all for the help! Once I get a little more experience with my phone, hopefully I can help someone else with questions.

Admitted iphone fanatic aka isheep. 
I notice the longer I use the phone and charge when needed the better the battery performance becomes.

I have mine on Power Save Mode with just restrict performance cpu restriction on and I notice excellent battery life and I always close down apps after use too!
Posted via the Android Central App

I had the same problem. I solved my problem by using the charger that came with the phone. I was using an old MicroUSB and the battery would lose power like crazy, once i switched back to the original charger that came with the phone the problem was solved. 
I'm hoping that is your problem too. If you are using the original charger i do not know how to help.

title: Photo/Video upload Issue??

thread.text: I just wondered if anybody else has had this problem. I synced my S5 to my pc to upload some photos/videos. When my pc is finished importing my photos all kinds of other pictures and screencaps show up. For example, a whole bunch of screenshots of games that i do not play or have on my phone. Also, audio files from my GPS (turn by turn audio), and pictures that have "allegedly" been erased. It is very annoying...... So, has anybody else had a similar issue? Do I need to transfer my photo/video files to an SD card and upload it to the pc that way (if i can). I've tried looking for those other weird pics on my phone's gallery and other places and I can't find them ANYWHERE!! Plus, I know these lousy unwanted files are just taking up space. Thank you all in advance for your help!!!

Which method are you using to back up the files? If they are transferring to your PC they are SOMEWHERE. Most likely in hidden folders in your phone. 
If you use Google+ auto-backup, there's an option to back up just your camera folder or to do so with all media from any other folders (you can further select which ones if activated).

Welcome to Android Central! It sounds like you're using the Import Photos function on Windows Explorer. That will bring in all images including thumbnails and images used by apps. I suggest just using Windows Explorer to manually select which photos you want to copy to the computer, and drag and drop them. Don't bother with the Import Photos function.
Yeah guys i was using the import photos on windows.. I will definitely use windows explorer to drag the photos!!! Thank you very much.

I have mine in a Case Mate Sport that I got at the AT&T store. It is a very close match to my red phone, but they had other colors. The back is a dark gray and will hold credit cards or DL/ID in a slot.

Bad: curved back makes it wobble when you type on a desk and spin around if you bump it with your finger inadvertently when reaching for it. Annoying enough that I don't use it now.

Chris

I believe by the looks of it my Case Mate Sport is slightly bulkier than the Body Glove. The back is a harder plastic so it will slide if set on a smooth surface but it is flat. If it is set face down the outer rim is grippier (is that a real word?) and it doesn't slide around so easily. Another possible "feature" is that the card slot on the back allows for air circulation to the back of the phone. Might not work so much if you have a couple of cards in there but mine is open and I have noticed no heat build up. I still wish Ballistic would make a Hybrid type case for the S5 Active, I had excellent luck with one when my old Motorola was dropped several times and sustained no damage.

I'm really happy with my Case Mate Hula. I got the red S5 Active becasue I think it looks awesome, and hated to hide it in a case since it's already supposed to be rugged. I was just worried about corners & I didn't feel like the sides give a positive grip. This case gives you a nice lip around the screen, and the black/clear looks nice (at least on my phone), while leaving the back exposed. It doesn't add any bulk and slides in and out of the pocket easily, but not too easily.

Love the new features..
Congrats on your new phone!

title: Questions for S5 Active owners:

thread.text:
Heys guys,
Im debating between purchasing an S5 active or regular S5 and have a couple questions. I know its unlikely any of you have had both phones, but I figure some of you may have had the chance to try both.
1. Battery life:
Both phones have identical hardware and batteries (with the exception of no fingerprint scanner or usb 3.0 on the active). Therefore both phones should have identical battery life. I have read reviews that suggest the battery life of the active is slightly worse. Can anyone confirm or disprove this?
2. Charge time:
S5 has usb 3.0, active has 2.0. I believe 3.0 utilizes higher current. Is the charge time of the active significantly slower or even perceptibly slower?
3. Water resistance:
I know the S5 and active should be submersible to some extent. I have read reviews about the active getting wet (not even submerged) and it causing damage. Has anyone experienced this first hand?
4. Pocket dialing:
I also read a review talking about how the active's physical buttons caused pocket dialing regularly. Have any of you experienced this? For those of you that have, is there a solution besides using a pass code/pattern?
5. Temperature testing:
I plan to use this phone when snowboarding and hiking regularly. The phone will likely see single digit temps. I have had problems with every phone I have ever owned turning off in cold temps. Has anyone actually tested the extreme temperature range this phone claims it operates within?
Thanks in advance

replies.text:
I can't really say much to the battery difference. I too plug mine in every night. No complaints and no worse than most other smart phones
I've heard others complain about whether it's waterproof or not but you just don't know whether people put their covers back onproperly or had the charging plug covered like you should. There have certainly been those who had no problem with water and some have even taken pictures under water. I myself prefer not to tempt the gods. :-)
I have never **** dialed with this phone but I would definitely agree that the power button gets hit several times a day putting in and out of things. It's an annoyance to be sure but there are ways around it. I absolutely love the look and feel of this phone. Very solid (definitely more so than the regular S5). I have no regrets over my purchase.

thread.text:
I only have experience with the Active, but here are some observations:
1. Battery life is great, I'm on the phone at least 15-20 times a day with clients, use GPS all the time (I never turn off location), take photos of before and after my work, and if I'm in the car, bluetooth is on for music. Phone goes on at 0600, off at 2300, I still have at least 50% left. I have gone 2 full days between charges if I forget to plug it in, but I've never had a dead battery.
2. I plug mine in overnight, so I cannot answer this, I have no idea how long it takes to charge.
3. My phone has been wet many times, I work outside in all weather conditions. None of the "water damage" stickers have changed color, and the phone runs perfectly.
4. This was my one complaint. The power button is WAY to easy to push when you put the phone in your pocket, turning on the display, and leaving the phone open to booty-dialing, so choosing the pattern lock is almost mandatory. I solved this by getting a bumper case from the AT&T store. Sure, I overpaid at almost $16.00 for 0.40 cents of plastic and rubber, but I like it, and the charging port is still accessible. Best of all, the power button is much harder to push inadvertently. 
5. As I said, I'm outdoors all day, the phone works at 105F just like it works at 22F, it snowed almost 2 inches here the other day, and yes, I did use the Active during a period that was close to white-out (I couldn't see across the street), and while the touchscreen doesn't work all that well when wet (although it was visible), the phone stayed dry inside. 
I hope you end up with the phone that makes you happiest, in my particular case, the Active is the choice. The built-in ruggedness, slightly more camera lens protection, and better charging port design are all icing on the cake that is this phone.

title: Coming from LG G3! How do you like the Active?

thread.text:
Hey guys.. I'm getting my S5 Active today. Had a g3 but had issues like crazy with 3 phones.. After 2 hours with AT&T relations, they agreed for me to pick a new phone.. So I'm a mechanic and workout. So I picked the S5 Active.. 
How do you guys like it so far? Also please don't tell me all your problems. I don't want to look for them. Lol. I had enough of them with my g3..

replies.text: I didn't come from a G3 but it was one of the 2 others I was thinking of before I got my active. I'm very happy with my choice. In the end it came down to a couple of things. I was fairly concerned about the G3's screen and how it would affect battery life and then of course if I went that way, it would mean giving up my Gear 2 although I read of one guy who managed to side load Gear Manager onto the G3 and made it work. I don't want to even deal with all of that. To my way of thinking, things work better together if they were designed to work that way. Besides, there was no getting away from how the Active felt in my hand. I loved it. I dislike iPhones immensely but I will admit that they feel good in the hand (that's all I'll give it). The Active is the first phone I've really felt was made solid since maybe the LG MyTouch Slide (an oldie but goodie). I still like Samsung a lot, I just wish they'd build their phones a little better. If they did that, they'd blow iPhones out of the water. They did in fact do that with the Active and I am very happy with it. Not to big and not to small and works great.

thread.text:
Welcome to the club; I'm quite happy with my S5 Active but that's this week. I tend to change phones more than my underwear. I have yet to find a phone that handles outdoor light better, I haven't found the detail on it but it has some form of ultra saturation mode that washes out some colors but is extremely bright. If you want to root your phone to gain access to things like Titanium Backup or SD Card fix or custom ROMs you will need to take some more extreme efforts, for me it's worth it. At&t S 5 Active Restore Thread (NE4) | AT&T Galaxy S 5 | XDA Forum
I'd also recommend a tempered glass screen protector, they fit nicely on this phone and protect against that one time you have sand in your pocket and scratch the screen. People claim it helps against drops, I'm not sold on that but if true is a nice added bonus. I also rotate batteries, nicer than constantly plug, just run it dead and swap.
I'm sure there is more I will think of as the day goes on.

Thanks guys for all the replies. I'm really looking forward to this phone. My wife just called, it's home and delivered. I'm anal about my phone too. I ordered a glass screen protector too and a case. Won't be there till tomorrow. So I will have to wait 1 more day before playing with it. Lol

The guy at the AT&T store was trying to get me to go with the LG G3, because you get some deal on a tablet with it. I had an LG phone years ago, back when flip phones were popular, and the battery on that was horrible, so I've stayed away from LG phones since then. I knew what I wanted when I walked into the store and nothing was going to change my mind. I love the S5 Active, the only difference is that it doesn't have a fingerprint scanner (which I'd never use anyway) and it doesn't use USB 3.0 like the normal S5.
It has a great screen and is really fast at multitasking, which is what I was looking for in a phone. The only thing I have a problem with is the little thing that covers the USB port, it always gets in the way when I try to plug my phone in at night.

replies.text: I played with it a little last night. Did not activate it yet. Waiting on my screen protector and case first. I noticed the cover too on the charging port.. Feels like it's going to break.. Lol..

Those things are curiously strong I think. My daughter showed me a way to deal with it quickly otherwise it tends to get in the way when you try to plug it in. If that's all I have to complain about, I'll live with it. I love this thing. I notice that the only time this phone gets bad reviews is when someone drops it or gets water on it and it doesn't hold up. I have no idea if that's all there is to the story and I get this phone is supposed to be strong but really I treat this like any other phone - never drop it and NEVER get it wet. The way I handle my phone, that is very unlikely to happen but it's nice to know I stand a better chance of surviving such an event with this phone. Regardless of how well its made, I doubt you could drop any phone face down on cement or a hard floor and not have it break. For the record though, I've also had people tell me they actually took their phone under water and took pictures with it without issue. Sounds great but I'll just leave it alone and not tempt the cell phone gods.

You are exactly like me with phones. Just because it's more durable, doesn't mean I'm going to treat it any different.. I take care of my phones.. Can't wait to actually activate it and use it tonight. Hopefully my signal and reception is better then my g3.. That was terrible.. I'll let you know how it goes. And I will only use underwater cameras.. Lol. Not my phone..

On the other hand, I have an iPhone 4s for work (yuk) and I just put a Defender Otterbox on it that they sent me. That thing feels like a tank. Wouldn't mind putting that to the test since it isn't mine.

thread.text: I learned something, which may sound kind of odd, but we're going to go with it. I was on the phone with my mother the other night and usually it's a 3 hour long session of her talking about this and that, which can become tiresome, and make me lose track of things I should or want to be doing. I put her on speakerphone, because smartphones have never been comfortable for long periods of time up to my ear. After about an hour I got the idea of leaving her on speakerphone, putting the phone down, and taking a shower. Now this is the point I'm trying to make, she never once actually knew I was in the shower and when I told her afterward, she told me that she never even heard the water running. That's how good the speakerphone seems to be on this phone. I remember with my S3, she could always hear the water running when I would wash the dishes, so it seems that it wouldn't be a problem with this phone, being that she couldn't hear the shower going.

replies.text: So what if that whole time she asked you a question? Could she still hear you or vice versa? Lol. Funny story. She sounds like my mom. .lol

title: Display brightness outdoors

replies.text: My dad has an s3. I have the S5 Active and my active is brighter. Not by much. But it's awesome

thread.text: The S5 Active also has this saturated super bright mode that will come on when it detects direct sunlight. It's great for things like maps or basic email but makes everything else look washed out. This is the first phone I've had do this and I appreciate it as I have a convertible and the maps are now legible when my top is down.

Yep, I've had the S5 Active for about a month now. I like it very much!
I picked mine up yesterday and am very happy with the choice. Downsized a little from my previous phone but still plenty big enough to get the job done. Love the look and feel of it.

Purchased it from at&t without looking into it first. They make you buy the phone now by hiding the cost in your bill for 24 payments. Don't get me wrong, I love the phone but, If I knew I was going to pay full price I would have purchased it from another place with a unlocked bootloader and sim. I upgraded from the Skyrocket with Cyanogenmod 11 and loved flashing new roms. A little disappointed but had root that weekend and used titanium backup to re-install everything from my Skyrocket. Going good so far. Great powerful phone.
Can't get the Active anywhere but AT&T. Sprint has the "sport" version but it's not quite the same.

I currently have a pretty good phone but I have to admit, the S5 Active is really pulling at me for some reason. My daughter has one and while I don't necessarily need the protective features of it (I NEVER drop, fold, spindle, or mutilate my phone), I just really like the look and feel of this phone. I'm thinking VERY seriously of pulling the trigger on it tomorrow.
Got mine about a month ago and really liking it!
Update: Picked me up a gun metal grey active this morning and so far I really like it. I haven't had it long enough to give a comprehensive opinion but so far I'm liking it a LOT.

I just upgraded to one yesterday morning (the camo one). I love it so far! Although, I don't plan on dropping mine or submerging it in water, but I love the feel of it in my hand. It's a big step going from the S3 to this. I got my boyfriend one also, he spent all day trying to figure it out. Hah! I even tried the ultra power saving mode, and my phone stayed at 9% for 10 hours until I decided to charge it. I made the switch due to my boyfriend having battery drain issues after the S3 received the 4.4 update (and mine wouldn't update at all) and he's relieved to see that this phone lasts forever on one charge.

replies.text: I actually came from another high end phone to this, not because I didn't like it or it didn't work (great phone). I'm just the type that needs to try new things on a regular basis and like you, I love the feel of this phone in my hand. very solid. I also never drop my phone (seriously) and I certainly have no plans to have it go swimming. I just really like the look and feel.

Only problem is turning on the screen when in pocket and it randomly going to all sorts of apps.
I'd like to see what the under water pictures would look like, but I'm not comfortable with my phone going under water, even if it's able to.
Sent from my Galaxy S5 Active using Tapatalk

I know this sounds overly simplistic but I've found that since it's a flat back phone I can put it in my pocket screen out and never have a tap on issue. Might be a risk for impact but hey that region is always at risk of impact.
